title: Max Payne Voice Actor James McCaffrey, The Heart Of Remedy Games, Dies At 65
description:
James McCaffrey, the longtime voice actor who has brought numerous key characters in Remedy Entertainment's games to life, has passed away at the age of 65.

The news was first reported by TMZ, saying a rep confirmed that he died on Sunday surrounded by friends and family after a battle with multiple myeloma. Actor Kevin Dillon had earlier posted a message on Instagram indicating that McCaffrey had died.

Remedy addressed his passing in a post on X/Twitter, saying, "We are deeply saddened to hear about the passing of our beloved friend and collaborator James McCaffrey, the iconic voice of Max Payne and Alex Casey. His remarkable talent not only gave life to our characters but also left an enduring impact on our community. Our hearts go out to his family in this time of loss."<

title: Dev Behind Highly Regarded PC Game Explains Why He Raised The Price: "Go Pirate It, I Don't Care"
description:
David Szymanski, the developer behind the critically acclaimed PC games Dusk and Iron Lung, has raised the price of his newest game and says it's because he wants to make more money.

Szymanski recently raised the price of Iron Lung from $6 to $8, and he responded to people on social media who were apparently trying to "gotcha" him. "Once again, Iron Lung's price went up because the game is worth $8 so I want to charge $8, because I want to earn more money. If you don't agree with this price, I don't want your money. Go pirate it or something idc," he said.

He went on to say he raised the price due to "added value/content." The price change was announced in October and went into effect in November.

title: Barbie Movie Boss Responds To Sequel Rumors And Says There Is "So Much" Crossover Potential
description:
The Barbie movie exceeded expectations this year, bringing in more than $1.4 billion globally to become 2023's biggest movie. Robbie Brenner, the head of toy company Mattel's movie division, Mattel Films, has now said the film is "a unicorn."

Barbie was Mattel Films' first movie, and it sets an impossibly high bar for the company going forward as it looks to adapt its other franchises into films. Brenner said, "The only thing that I can do is to just focus on each project, individually."

title: You Can Finally Watch Luigi In Action In Super Mario 64, Sort Of
description:
A video uploaded to a small Japanese YouTube account last month has become an important part of video game history. A seconds-long section of the video appears to show the first-ever known footage of Luigi in Super Mario 64.

The 13:20 mark of the video--which was uploaded to the Now In Game Channel account on November 22--shows a brief look at a few monitors at Nintendo's booth from the 1995 Space World convention in Japan. One of the monitors flashes to a room with checkerboard flooring, while a tall figure in a green shirt, green hat, and overall performs the SM64 spin jump and floats to the ground.

We finally have a glimpse of what the early multiplayer mode for Super Mario 64 looked like! This is also the first time we have seen Luigi's SM64 model outside of the Nintendo Leaks! Take a look!

title: Bill Murray Returns To New Ghostbusters To Help The New Generation
description:
Ghostbusters: Afterlife revived the original Ivan Reitman film continuity with Egon Spengler's (the late Harold Ramis) grandchildren taking over the proton packs and becoming the next generation of 'busters--with some adult supervision by Mr. Grooberson (Paul Rudd).

While Jason Reitman directed Afterlife, he's handing the reins to Gil Kenan (who wrote Afterlife and the upcoming sequel Frozen Empire with Reitman) and now begins the new chapter in Ghostbusters stories.

Talking with Empire Magazine, Kenan talked about bringing the new Ghostbusters into a post-Gozerian world, and confirmed that Dan Akroyd, Ernie Hudson, and Bill Murray will return once again as Ray Stantz, Winston Zeddmore, and Peter Venkman. title: Gary Oldman On How Batman And Harry Potter "Saved" Him
description:
Oscar-winning actor Gary Oldman has said the major movie franchises he starred in--Batman and Harry Potter--"saved" him and his home life. Appearing on The Drew Barrymore Show (below), Oldman said he turned down many opportunities to star in movies because they filmed in far-away places like Prague, Australia, and Budapest because he wanted to spend more time with his sons.

Then, at age 46, he was cast as Sirius Black in the Harry Potter movie series, and then he landed another huge role a few years later as Commissioner Gordon in Christopher Nolan's Batman series. These movies required less travel and paid better, allowing Oldman the time and resources to raise his children.

title: The Original Xbox Console Almost Had An "Awkward" Naming Scenario
description:
Have you ever spent countless nights awake pondering the correct collective noun for all of your Xbox consoles? Xboxes sound weird, and according to the father of that Microsoft console, there was almost something weirder floating around when the console was being developed. According to Seamus Blackley, who created and designed the original Xbox in 2001, there was a strong argument against keeping the console's internal name of DirectXbox, as the pluralized form of that word was the "most awkward" when it was brought up.

This was one of the arguments AGAINST keeping the internal name (directX box -> Xbox), as the plural was awkward. I was a fan of the MOST AWKWARD of course…
OX -> OXEN
Xbox -> Xboxen 😂 https://t.co/zBUArfUA7q pic.twitter.com/zfDMS74oGB

— Seamus Blackley (@SeamusBlackley)
